metadata.case_name: Basti Sugar Mills Co. Ltd., Nawabganj Sugar Mills Co. Ltd. & Punjab Sugar Mills Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: Basti Sugar Mills Co. Ltd. owned sugar factories at Basti and Waltharganj.
Prior to 1944, selling agent of appellants was M/s Gursarandas Kapur Sons at Kanpur.
On July 26, 1944, Board of Directors of Basti Sugar Mills resolved to appoint M/s Gokul Nagar Sugar Mills Co. Ltd. as selling agents at 0-12-0 commission.
For assessment year 1947-48 of Basti Sugar Mills, ITO allowed deduction of Rs. 47,921/- as commission to selling agents by order dated June 21, 1949.
For assessment year 1952-53 of Nawabganj Sugar Mills, ITO issued notice dated March 29, 1954 under s.34(1)(a) of Income-tax Act, 1922 disallowing selling commission.
For Nawabganj Sugar Mills assessment year 1948-49, ITO allowed Rs. 60,980/- commission deduction by order dated February 28, 1951.
For Nawabganj 1949-50, commission to selling agent allowed as deduction.
For Nawabganj 1952-53, ITO issued notice dated January 19, 1957 questioning commission deduction.
For Punjab Sugar Mills 1947-48, commission Rs. 37,978/- to Gokul Nagar allowed by order dated February 27, 1950.
Managing agent of all three appellant companies is M/s Narang Brothers Ltd., Chairman Dr. Gokulchand Narang.
ITO held all companies controlled by Dr. Gokulchand Narang, Gokul Nagar also controlled by him, no services rendered by Gokul Nagar as selling agent.
AAC allowed some deductions for sub-agents but upheld disallowance of main commission to Gokul Nagar.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal by common order dated December 31, 1962 rejected claim, no privity of contract, direct dealings by appellants with sub-agents, action under s.34 justified.
Appellants applied under s.66(1) to Tribunal for reference of 4 questions, rejected February 19, 1965.
Delhi High Court by order March 14, 1967 directed reference of question 4 only, rejected 1-3 as questions of fact.
Evidence adduced: oral from Ram Sahai Dhir and Shiv Nand Verma, receipts 948 (April 24, 1946) and 298 (Feb 13, 1947).
Telegram Sept 1, 1948 from Chairman Nawabganj to M/s Ramdev & Co. terminating Gursarandas and directing Ramdev to sell.
ITO summoned Dr. Gokul Chand Narang under s.37, produced 13 letters in personal capacity on Gokulchand Ram Sahai letterheads, no replies.

legal_issues.text: Whether Tribunal justified in holding no services rendered by M/s Gokul Nagar Sugar Mills Co. Ltd. to Nawabganj Sugar Mills Co. Ltd.
Whether Tribunal justified without taking into account statement of Shri Ram Sahai Dhir and receipts showing commission paid to sub-agents.
Whether Tribunal rightly concluded Dr. Sir G.C. Narang signed letters as Chairman of Nawabganj when no capacity to deal with sub-agents.
Whether Tribunal legally justified in holding s.34(1)(a) rightly invoked.

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal failed to consider material evidence like testimony of Ram Sahai Dhir and Shiv Nand Verma, receipts 948 and 298.
High Court noted Tribunal made no reference to evidence of two witnesses and receipts.
Tribunal must judicially consider all evidence in favour and against assessee.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Udhavdas Kewalram v. CIT, Bombay City (1967) 66 ITR 462

respondent_arguments.text: All authorities including Tribunal considered relevant material, findings that no services by Gokul Nagar, direct dealings by appellants.

court_reasoning.text: Questions 1-3 are purely questions of fact.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Resolution of 1944 exists but no other evidence on how carried out.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal considered evidence of Ram Sahai Dhir via Ramdev & Co. relationship and telegram showing direct dealing.
Shiv Nand Verma's evidence rejected as he claimed appointment in 1942 before Gokul Nagar appointed.
Receipts not specifically mentioned but insignificant given rejected witness evidence and only two produced over years.
Tribunal acted judicially, considered all material, findings based on evidence and reasonably reached.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agrees with High Court no question of law.

holdings.text: No substance in appeals; Tribunal properly appreciated evidence; no question of law arises from questions Nos. 1 to 3.
High Court correctly declined to direct reference of questions 1-3.
Tribunal must consider all material judicially as per Udhavdas Kewalram, which it did.

precedents_cited.case_name: Udhavdas Kewalram v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City
precedents_cited.relevance: Tribunal must judicially consider all evidence; order ignoring evidence not conclusive on facts.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Notice for reassessment; summoning documents; reference to High Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals by special leave against Delhi High Court order dated March 14, 1967, holding no question of law arises from questions Nos. 1 to 3 sought to be referred, affirming Tribunal's factual findings that no services rendered by selling agent warranting commission deduction.

key_quotes.text: the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal has to act judicially and consider all the evidence in favour and against the assessee
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Cites principle from Udhavdas on Tribunal's duty.

key_quotes.text: there is no substance in these appeals.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: No doubt, there is a resolution produced by the appellants dated July 26, 1944... There is no other evidence to show the nature of the arrangement
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Highlights insufficiency of evidence beyond resolution.
